column4: The whole point of iceweasel was to get around branding restrictions caused by Debian's refusal to package Firefox without updates unapproved by Mozilla. Ubuntu complies with Mozilla's update/branding policy, so it doesn't need Iceweasel.
the whole point was that Debian wanted to improve some stuff.
then the Mozilla guys said: fine, but you need to rebrand it.
so, why doesn't Ubuntu have the same improvements?
If you look back at the discussion when it happened, it wasn't about improving anything. That came later.
I read the discussion when it happened.

Firstly, Mozilla got mad at Debian for unapproved packaging. Debian then turned around and decided that the branding policy was non-dfsg free. Then, we ended up with Iceweasel. Any customization or improvement of Iceweasel over Firefox came later.
The Mozilla guys were afraid of getting a bad name in theory and legally that they were afraid of losing the brand.
anyone could call something Firefox.
they wanted to avoid that.
